div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,375] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisl Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Malls arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternnon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convienent hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisl or vial Marseilles
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an avatement of 25 percent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steemers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Adenspo Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
Messrs Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt) Ltd. - Cairo.
Grosen Royle Reg - Port Said.
Mussers Hasulden and Co. - Alexandria.
F G Davidson Superintendent P and O. S. N. Company in Egypt - Suez.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: FEMALE PRIMARY EDUCATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: The growing demand for female education is one of the signs of the times in Egypt, and the references to this subject in the speech pronounced by Sheikh Che rif last Sunday on the occasion of the solemn distribution of the subventions granted to the fikie and Arifs of the Cairo kuttabs deserve the special attention of all who have the welfare of the younger generation at heart We have frequently referred to the educational movement that has become widespread during the past year in the country districts as well as the towns, and we are glad to see that for the first time sines the days of Amr and the early rulers of Egypt, the Moslems of this country are bestirring themselves with a view to obtaining education for their daughters. This year no less than 10,359 girls are receiving primary instruction in the kat-tabs and there is no reason whatever for apprehending any reaction. The facts point in the other direction. The growth of education among all classes of Moslems in Egypt must inevitably cause a demand for educated wives. Men who can read and write and nave acquired a fair primary education are unlikely to rest satisfied with the knowledge that their prospective wives are illiterate and ignorant, and the better-educated are certain to demand educational facilities for girls more and more eagerly. That there are difficulties in the way is obvious enough. A mixed education of boys and girls, except the very youngest, is perhaps unsuited to the country and is certain to make many parents shy of sending their girls to school, but the Ministry of Public Instruction is taking steps to meet this difficulty. It has already made a beginning by transform ing the three Cairo kuttabs of Sheikhoun el Kebir, Saidah Zeynab, and Eabbanieh into girls' schools. Mistresses have been obtained from the Saaieh Normal School and the result of the experiment has been that a number of parents have promptly sent their daughters to. these three kattabs, among them several persons of note who were formerly most bitter opponents of female education. These three girls' kuttabs, though opened only a few months ago, already contain no less than 357 papils,—figures which augur well for the future of female education in Egypt.

div.head: SITUATION IN RUSSIA. THE POLICY OF REPRESSION. CONSIDERED TO BE NEARER END.
div.p: The polity of repression adopted by the authorities having entirely tailed, although the crisis is now more grave, it is considered as being Dearer an end.

div.head: Rudolph Home.
div.p: Mrs. Sidney H. Carver has generously sent the sum of PT. 5071, with a promise of a farther donation, in order to provide Christmas dinners for the poor. Mrs. Barker has also sent a Christmas plum pudding to the Home.
Accident at Cairo.

A native cartman was walking alongside his horse yesterday morning, when, owing to the condition of the road after a slight shower, he slipped and was crushed under the wheels of the cart, which was heavily laden with sand. The police made the usual investigation.
A. L. M. & D. S.

The lecture on "The Desert of Sinai," which Dr. Ruffer, C.M.G., has kindly consented to repeat for the members of the Alexandria Literary, Musical & Dramatic Society in the Parish Room, Bulkeley, on Tuesday next, will begin at 5.30 p.m. Members of the society will be admitted free and non-members on payment of P.T. 2.
Cairo Weather.

Oar Cairo Correspondent writes under data of yesterday — We are having the first spell of real winter weather. The day has been cold, dull and cloudy. There wag a little rain in the forenoon and also in the afternoon. The prospects of to-morrow's weather for the fir-t day of the first winter meeting of the K. S. C. are not promising.
Garrison Church.

On Friday evening next, at 6 o'clock, the new organ in H.B.M.'s Garrison Church of St. George, Mustapha Pasha, will be dedicated and opened. There will be a short service and an address by the Rev. Canon Ward, M.A., chaplain of St. Mark's. Mr. Heaton, organist of St. Mark's, has kindly promised to give a recital of sacred music. All are cordially invited. The service will last about 50 minutes.
Interesting Case of Pre-emption.

A very interesting case of pre emption will in all probability come before the Cairo Mixed Courts shortly. One of the best-known hotels in the neighbourhood of Cairo was recently sold to an hotel company for £100,000 and now a claim to pre-empt has been made. Negotiations have been opened with a view to get the would be pre-emptors to abandon their claim, but it is very doubtful if they will be successful.
Sale of Work.

We are requested to draw the attention of our readers again to the sale of work which will take place at the Sailors and Soldiers' Institute to-morrow (Thursday) at 3 p.m. The band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers will, by the kind permission of the Colonel and officers, play daring the afternoon. Anyone wishing to enjoy a pleasant hour will be heartily we!-comed without of necessity making any purchase. A fine Christmas Tree has been provided, which will doubtless prove a great attraction. Visitors are requested to Dote that the entrance will be from the side door.

div.head: THE RAIYAN PROJECT.
div.p: DEPARTMENT OF STATE'S ACTION.
LETTER FROM MR. COPE WHITEHOUSE.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—The Department of State has instructed the Diplomatic Agent of the United States to ascertain what evidence exists in the Departments of the Egyptian Government that I took all necessary steps to secure a concession of the Wadi Mullah; as well as of my application for the W 'di Raiyan, at a time when the Public Works Ministry denied that any such depression existed.

In 1882, papers were published by me in Paris, in the ''Revue Archdolog'que" ; in London, in the "Atbei eeum" ; and in New York, in the ''Proceedings" of the American Geographical Society, with an opinion by Chi Justice Daly. It was, however, in 1883, that the "Egyptian Gazette" published a communication by Dr. Schweinfurth, which was adopted as a bulletin by the Khedivial Geographical Society, and immediately commanded the assent of the entire scientific world, with the notable exception of M. Maspero. Prior to my researches, the existence of a great Lake Moeris was universally denied, chiefly on the authority of Dr. Lepsias and the German expeditions. Dr. Lepaius explicitly stated that the Fayoum was only about 90 feet below the Nile Valley, and that the rains at Dimeh were "near" the Birket el Qerun. and below the level of low Nile. As they were, also, in his opinion, older than the Fifth Century B.C., he regarded this as conclusive that the Fayoum had never been submerged within the historic period. As a matter of fact, I found, in 1882, when I employed Tristram Ellis to accompany me and verify my observations, that these rains were higher than high Nile at Beni Scef. This was published many years before the Egyptian Government authorised Sir Hanbury Brown to ran a line of levels from the Lake, over Dimeh, to the anoient temple, whose existence I had slso indicated, plainly visible trom Dimeh. therefore any attempt to take from me the credit of reopening the question of Lake Moeris, and its identfication with a submerged Fayoum, is sufficiently refated by a reference to the columns of the "Egyptian Gazette," or any of the numerous papers, written by eminent Egyptologists, prior to 1884, of which a, list can be found in my Memoir, entitled - Moeris, the Wonder of the World." Copies of this pamphlet can be found in every public library of importance. Sir Hanbury Brown's volume, with its beautiful photographs, adds nothing to what I had previously printed, except a dissentient opinon about n y identification of the Liens Meridis of the later Ptolemaic period with the Wadi Raiyan I had spent many days with Sir Hanbury Brown, and given him my pamphlets and maps, before I learned, through the inadvertent admission of his brother, that he intended to write a book, which I regarded as premature. Dr. Flinders Petrie was my engineer in two expeditions, in 1882, employed by me to secure a witness to my observations, and had no right to communicate the results without my permission, much less to put himself forward as having made any original investigations. His error's in regard to the Pyramids in Lake Moeris. and the height of the ridge between the Gharag and Raiyan Basins, are suffioient to show the sources of his knowledge and his misconception of my statements, in an attempt to import into them an originality of his own of which they were not susceptible.

In 1883, I indicated to Lord Dnfferin, Gen. Sir John Ardagh, Sir Colin Scott Moncrieff, and Mr. Moberly Bell, with many others, the probable value of the Wadi Raiyan, and Sir C. C. Scott Moncrieff mentions Lake Moeris in his preliminary report on the use of the million from the guaranteed loan. In September, 1885, ' Engineering" published an exhaustive article, written by Its editor, which is the Magna Charta of the Raiyan Projeot. It misleading to say, as the Public Works Ministry has done, on repeated occasions, that the Raiyan depression was mentioned by Linant de Bellefonds on his hydrographic map, prepared for Mehemet Ali. The Ain Raiyan, and the Raiyan Oases, were known to every Arab frequenting the route to the Little Oasis, and are the first camping station to the South of Gharag, but Linant expressly stated, in 1873, as I showed in try testimony before M. Boule, Sir B. Baker, and Sig. Torri-oe'li, in 1894, that he supposed that these Oases were higher than tre cultivated land of Gharag. It seems to me unworthy of a Government to repeat, again and again, since 1889, a statement, which is technically accurate (because the Wadi Raiyan is a depression), with the obvious intention of implying that every one knew that it was available as a flood escape and reservoir, although the fire-most cartographer of Egypt, Dr. Schwein-fnrth, expressly disclaimed any such knowledge in 1888, and a special meeting of The Khedivial Geographical Society had been. held to examine the evidence on which it has been placed upon the maps. It escapes the observation of these writers that Lord Cromer informed the Marquis of Salisbury, in 1887, that I had discovered "a new and unknown depression," and Col. Western describes it "discovered by Mr. Cope Whitehouse," in his official report on the Raiyan Project.

The dossier of the Wadi Muellah was in a complete and perfect state, whan it was approved by Blum Pasha,, and the Hodja was submitted to the President of the Council of Ministers. It was, subsequently, seen by me In the bands of the official charged with its

custody ; and Sir Eldon Gorat wrote me a letter referring to it If, therefore, it is true that it "does not exist," it has been destroyed; and the object of the instructions sent to the Diplomatic Agent of the United States is to ascertain, when and by whose orders this destruction took place. It appears from the publication this year of an official report on this valley, that a stone house was in course of erection, but it is not stated whether this bad been done with the sanction of the Government.

The Raiyan project is as much mine as the picture of an artist, or the manuscript of a book. In view of the necessity of changing the maps of Egypt, so as to introduce upon them the depression, it might even be said that the artist had also woven his own oanvas, or the author manufactured the paper on which he had written.

The Wadi Muellah is mine. I offered to buy it, fearing lest use might be made of it to impose some improper terms on the inhabitants ot Egypt, when the Raiyan project was carried into execution. There is hieroglyphic evidenoe of a canal named Tomi leaving the Bahr Jusnf near Behnesa. But Sir C. C. Scott Moncrieff insisted upon my taking it, without the trifling fee for registration, accompanied with an exemption from taxes for ten years. I have no doubt that he intended to act fairly ; but the result shows that it would have been much hotter for me, had he contented himself with permitting the transaction to pursue the ordinary course.

The two Houses of Congress will meet on the first Monday in December, and a resolution will be introduced, asking the Department of State to send to the Committees on Foreign Relations and Affairs, all the correspondence relating to the Raiyan project. A summary of what had taken place prior to 1887 was published by order of Congress in that year. The statement made, according to the former Diplomatic Agent, now Minister to Servia, by His Majesty's Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General that, if Mr. Cope White-house attempted to form a company, (in the United States) and proceeded to execute the projeot himself, he would be prevented by the authorities, seems to require explanation. At all events the Raiyan sluiceways would have been made at any time, since 1883, without any other cost to Egypt than the bare expenditure, to be repaid out of profits. It was declared feasible for £4.500,000 in the Parliamentary Report of 1891 ; and the American group stood ready to undertake it a year ago, withoat any remuneration to my self beyond the satisfaction of knowing that, at last, it would be done.
Cope Whitehouse.
Washington, November 30.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S INDISPOSITION.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive has sent Said Bey Zilfi kar, First Master of Ceremonies, to enquire after the health of Lord Cromer, who, we are glad to heir, is rapidly getting over his attack of dengue.

div.head: THE GRAND CADISHIP.
div.p: We understand that no reply has been sent by the Imperial Ottoman Government to the representations of the Egyptian Government concerning the appointment of the new Grand Cadi, and that for the present nothing has been decided as to the attitude which the authorities propose to take op in referenoe thereto.

It may here be said that, however the Government may regard the action of the Porte, no doubt whatever is entertained as to the personal qualifications of the new Grand Cadi for the post. Sheikh Jehladdin jlnmi has acquired a high reputation both for integrity and for knowledge of the Moslem sacred law at Meooa, where intrigue is rampant and honesty unfortunately at a preminm.

div.head: FINANCIAL ADVISERS' NOTE.
div.p: The Financial Advisers' Note on the Budget for 1906 will in all probability be published at the beginning of next week.

div.head: PERENNIAL IRRIGATION.
div.p: We understand that the Rakabahin and Kosbesha hods in Beni Sonef province are to be brought under perennial irrigation as soon as possible. The Council of Ministers has approved the decrees authorising the construction of the necessary canals and drains.

div.head: NOTES FROM TAHTA.
div.p: ( From our Correspondent. )
Tahta, Dec. 14.

Sir M. Mollwraith, the Judicial Adviser, arrived here to-dav by steamer, and in company with Tewfik Bey Rifaat, of the "Comite de Sarveillanoe," proceeded to the Native Court. Though his arrival happened to be at a late hour and was unexpected, the Judicial Adviser was pleased to find the whole staff of the tribunal at work. After inspecting the "Greffe" for over an hour he went hack to his steamer and left f or Sohag.

Ibrah m Bey Nabeeh, the new Moudir of Ghirgeh, arrived at Tahta yesterday. The sixty-five omdehs of the market awaited his arrival, together with some notables. He addressed this numerous assembly and impressed upon the omdehs the necessity for the maintenance of public security. He turned to the notables and drew their attention to the necessity also of improving the present oon-1 dition of the kuttabe in the villages and the establishment of new ones. He afterwards left for Sohag, promising to be hack op the 30th fast to preside over the distribution of "gran ts-' in-aid" to the fikis of kuttabs,

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY.
div.p: THE SULTAN'S SORE POINT.
WHY OTTOMANS SHUN EGYPT.
(From our own Correspondent).
Constantinople, Dec. 13.

It is amusing to note the way in which Egypt is placed on the Index Expnrgatorius of the Sublime Porte, save for its spies, of whom there must be a large number at Cairo. Egypt has always been a sore point with the Saltan, especially when he hears its perfect administration compared with that of Turkey, its nominal Suzerain. Not an Ottoman dare visit Egypt without fear of the immediate confiscation of his property and a summons issued for his prompt return—that is, should he have gone without a passport, to obtain which is an impossibility as far as Misr is concerned. Thus the Turks who flee to Cairo do so as voluntary exiles—to return would mean imprisonment. A Turkish official of good standing told the writer the other day that although on his way to Kanavan (he is a Sanitary Inspector) he passes Port Said, he would no more think of breaking the tedious journey - and it is tedious on board a Mahsnsseh steamer—by running up to Cairo than he would of occupying the Throne of the Caliphate.
Young Turks.

Of course there is a great mass of the Turkish population which is totally indifferent and happy, which vegetates rather than lives ; hut there is also an intellectual party, wrongly styled the Young Turk Party, who, having a glimpse of European civilization as reflected by the foreign social life, positively loathe their present miserable existence, which debars them from the joys of intellectual refinement because their imperfect education unfits them for life abroad, should ever they get away. In Egypt, however, according to all reports, these fugitives seem to get on better, as they have relatives or friends to hack them np, and there are not a few, mostly Army men, who are doing f drly well in the Khediviate.
Egyptian Independence.

Although nominally under Turkish rule the Egyptian Princes, Princesses, Beys, and others who prefer the Bosphorus to the Nile as a summer or permanent residence, enjoy all the political privileges of foreign colonists ; the Porte takes care not to meddle with them, and recognises them as a nation apart, so much so that the mails of the Khedivah Mother arriving from Egypt are sent direct to her place at Bebek instead of running the gauntlet of the Turkish Post Office.
The Khedivah's Bosphorus Palace.

Bebek, a picturesque and thoroughly Turkish village. on the European shore of the Bospborus, about half-way up the stream, has always been favorite resort for the Egyptian official world, ever since the days of the late Halim Pasha, whose enormous, ramshackle wool-built yali is next to the Rhedivah's Palace. This Khedivah's Palace fronts the sea ; it is built entirely of cement, even to the piling which supports it on the water side. This firm of con struction was very tedious, as each piece had to be separately moulded. The Palace contains 75 rooms, including an odg akuhan sati, or chapel, the Khedivah being very pious, as well as charitable. The Imam, a very fine-looking Egyptian, occupies a large and handsome wooden residence in the grounds, which are separated from the Palace premises by the public road, the connection being made by two Covered in ways, that have all the appearance of the famous Bridge of the Rialto. Behind the Imam's house is an electric installation, which, driven by an engine of 45 H. P., supplies the four hundred and odd lamps of the Palace. The household includes a staff of fourteen Ethiopians ; besides there are quite a host of cooks and lackeys, who are under the charge of Ali Bey, the Kilardji Bashi. The female department is ruled by a German lady, a very excellent person, who. however, has the greatest difficulty in keeping peace bet ween the domestics. I forgot to say that the rooms are tiled throughout and are absolutely impervious to damp. The hill rising somewhat abruptly above the Palace is densely wooded, and the ascent is made by a well levelled path zigzagging to the top, where there is a fairy-like kio quo shaded by a pine g ove. On such grand occasions as the Sultan's Accession Day, the Palace and grounds are resplendent with illuminations, the inscription "Padishahim Ichok yaaha" (Long life to my Sultan),in bold letters, crowning the hill just in front of the kiosqae. The Palace gardens are thrown open to the public, and the visitors, be they Turk, Greek, or American, are hospitably entertained.

The Khedivah is a warm-hearted Turcophile, and it may not be out of place here to mention that the present excellent relations existing between Turkey and Egypt are largely the outcome of the wise policy of the Khedive. Bebek is, praotioally speaking, a dependency of the Khedive h's Palace; at least nearly all the workpeople and trade-men are at the be à and calf of her Highness, who owns about helf the village, where a number of her retainers are in permanent residence. By the bye, I hear that she will come back to the Bosphorus from Egypt much earlier than usual this coming spring, Besides this Palace at Bebek, the Khedivial family has a residence at Tohihakii, on the Asiatic coast higher up, and the son of the Ute Halim Pasha lives at Yentkim. They have also a Tekke at Yeni Djami Stamboul, molding other properties, rot the least historical of which is Bulwer's Isle, with its sham castle and library. This building, converted into a farm house by a pair of bronze-faced Kelats was badly damaged the earthquake of 1894. It was sold by Henry Bulwer to the Khedive Ismail for L.T. 30,000,

div.head: THE RECENT RIOT.
div.p: THE ACTION IN THE MOSQUES.
ADVERSE COMMENT OF NATIVE PRESS

"Al Moayad" has some comments on the addresses of the sheikhs of Alexandria, which were delivered in the mosque on Friday last in the interests of public tranquillity. Our vernacular contemporary remarks :—

"Considerable responsibility rests with some one for calling upon the religions sheikhs to preach in the mosques advising people to avoid disturbances, and the Governor of Alexandria would not have undertaken this serious step had he not been authorised by the Government to do so. But requiring the sheikhs to exercise their religious influence in such a matter is tantamount to an acknowledgment on the part of the Government that religious fanaticism does exist among the Moslems and that it takes every precaution to suppress such fanaticism."

Among the precautionary measures in case of any disturbance at Alexandria at the end of last week, we may mention that a number of the Mounted Military Police, under the command of Captain Protheroe Smith, were held in readiness to leave Cairo at a moment's notice for Alexandria.

The precautions that were taken by Lewa Mansfield Pasha, the Commandant of the Cairo City Police, were excellent, and the Commandant deserves to be congratulated on the fact that his efforts have been in every respect successful. The Sheiks el Hara were ordered to prevent any gathering of persons in the streets and their orders were rigorously carried out It is considered in Cairo that a similar system should have been organised in Alexandria by the police, thereby preventing the sadden gathering of a huge mass of people in Mohamed Aly Square on Sunday week.

div.head: THE HOLY CARPET.
div.p: The transport of the Kiswet el Mahmal to the Mosque of Saida Zeynab will take place on Saturday next at 10 a m. H.H. the Khedive will preside over the ceremony. The usual military honors will be paid, Two deteachments of the 3rd Battalion with the Infantry Band will parade at 8 p.m. on Friday to escort the Holy Carpet from Koronfish to the Mohamed Aly-sqnare by Nahassine and Gamalieh streets.

On Saturday the Cairo garrison and the pupils of the Military School will parade at 9.30 a.m. for the Mahmal ceremony at Mohamed Aly-square. The force will be composed of the 3rd and 16th Battalions, the Cavalry, Artillery, and Maxim Battery. The Ministries and Government offices will be closed.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Yesterday and to-day the Supreme Consular Court at Alexandria has been occupied with the trial of Salvatore Camilleri, an ex-officer of the Alexandria City Police, accused of allowing a prisoner to escape. The case had not been concluded as we went to press.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE
div.p: Signs. Bellincioni scored another big success in her last night's performance of Traviata, and played to a large and very enthusiastic audience, on whom none of her points of excellence were lost. Albeit we have witnessed the diva's far-reaching powers in Toeca and Fedora and upon other occasions, we confess we were astonished at the utter change of dramatic colouration with which she can infuse her style. The plaintive sadness which she presented last night seemed to us all the more remarkable when contrasted with Tosoa's wild raving or the more determinate passion ot Fedora. It was perhaps her admirable rendering of the noble aria and brilliant allegro in Act I. which stirred her audience most. Acts II. and III. abound in exquisite duets with Alfredo and with his father, and, needless to say, full justice was done to them, while her death scene in the last act was in every way a masterpiece. The part of Alfredo was taken by Sig. Angiolo Bendinelli, whom we heard last night fer the first time, and whose voice is soft and expressive, with adequate, though not very powerful range. His handling of the part showed taste and sensibility and did much to deserve the applause which was liberally bestowed on him. Sig. Giovanni Polese gave a good account of the role of Germont pere, which he interpreted with discretion and refinement. The minor parts were all capably filled. The facile old-world music of Traviata did not impose very heavy duties on Sig. Zuccani and his orchestra, though he made excellent use of every opportunity, and in particular gave an essentially artistic rendering of the gentle overture to Act III. The chorus, especially the women's, again fell rather short Of the mark': when it was not hurried and unbalanced, it was mechanical and heavy.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Kaffir Prince, from Antwerp, left Malta on Monday, and is due at Alexandria on Friday.
The S.S. Sailor Prince is now loading for Manchester.
The Moss liner Menepthah arrived this morning from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiera, and Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIM.
div.p: CONSTRUCTION OP NEW FORT.
SALE OF BUILDING LANDS.
(From our Correspondent).
Suakin, December 13.

A new fort is being constructed by the 6 th Battalion Egyptian Army at Graham's Point, where several guns will be mounted to salute Lord Cromer when his lordship comes here for the opening of the Nile-Red Sea Railway. They will also be used for H. R. H. the Prince of Wales when he arrives here on his return from India.

H. E. the Governor of the Red Sea Ports, Kaimakam Hawker Bey, accompanied by Dr. Crispin, medical inspector, Suakin Moudirieh, left on a tour of inspection, on the 11th inst, by train as far as Gebeit and from there on camels to Erkoweit, Sinkat, etc. He will return here on the 15th inst.

On the completion of the Suakin-Atbara line a great reduction in the number of the staff and employes of the Suakin district will take place at the end of this year, in accordance with the Budget for 1906.

The Sudan Government intend shortly to sell lands at Port Sudan for building purposes, and several applications have already been received from individuals and companies, but the price and conditions of the Government have not yet been fixed. A Land Commission is to sit.

div.head: HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE.
div.p: The Hamburg-Amerika Company's liners Meteor and Mcltke arrive at Alexandria on the 16th January and the 27 th February respectively on pleasure cruise to the Mediterranean.

The old Cape liner Scot. which was recently purchased by this company, is now in dock at Hamburg. Her speed is to be increased to 21 knots. Owing to the work necessitated by this increase in speed she will not be ready this season, but next October she will come into service on the new line which the Hamburg Amerika Company is starting between Alexandria and Naples.

The fusion between the Hamburg-Amerika Line and the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company will be adopted at the adjourned general meeting of the latter oompany to be held next year. The fact of there having been no quorum at the meeting of the company, which was to have been held last Monday afternoon, fully demonstrates \that there is no opposition to the scheme, as it was never supposed there would be,considering the advantageous conditions which the share* holders of the Egyptian company are to obtain.

div.head: 'XMAS AT MENA.
div.p: On 'Xmas Eve (Sunday, 24th inst.) there will be a 'Xmas tree entertainment in the big dining hall of Mena House Hotel. The Bracale orchestra will perform during the afternoon.

The Bracale orchestra will perform during dinner on Boxing Day and for the small dance given by the management in the drawing-room the same night As a number of members of Cairo Society have already booked rooms for the 'Xmas holidays a select gathering is anticipated.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H R. H. Princess Louise is treating with the Anglo-American Nile Company for a special steamer for her Nile trip. The date of the Princess's arrival in Egypt is not yet definitely announced.

The Countess of Donoughmore and her daughter, Lady Norah hedy-Hutchinson, are arranging to leave for the Nile trip by one of the Anglo-American Company's steamers. The Countess and her daughter are staying at Shepheard's Hotel. The Countess is an American, the daughter of Mr. M. P. Grace of New York.
The second Earl of Donoughnore commanded the British Forces in Egypt in succession to Sir Ralph Aberoromby.

Dr. Edmund Robertson, M P., L.L.D., the newly appointed Secretary to the Admiralty who is staying at the Grand Hotel, Helouan, leaves Egypt on Christmas Day for London, in order to take up the duties of his office.

The following passengers left Cairo on Sunday by the P. S. Rameses: — Mr. and Mrs. J. H. Whitehouse, Mr. C.J. Whitehouse, Mrs. Ernest Hills, Miss Wynne Roberts, Sir Charles Scotter, Mrs. F. Scotter, Mr. C. R. Strong, Mr. and Mr. J. W. Chick, Mr. Chick, Miss Chick. Mr. and Mm. Philip S. Collins, Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. div.head:
THE FISCAL QUESTION
SPEECH BY MR. BALFOUR
THE LIBERAL PROJECTS.

div.p: Speaking at Leeds, Mr. Balfour said that the fiscal differences between Unionists have been greatly exaggerated, and that whether protec tion was right or wrong, his polioy of retaliation was without prejudice to it. His view was that protection is alien to the Im perial idea. In reference to preference, it was impossible to jadge the harden might impose till the whole scheme shall be developed and discussed at a Colonial confer* once. He therefore appealed for a suspension of judgment on this question. In any case Liberal projects were already authoritatively announced, especially Homs Kile. This should be quite sufficient to cause the Unionist ranks to rally.

div.head:
THE ATTEMPT ON THE SULTAN
PRISONERS CONDEMNED TO DEATH.

div.p: After public trial the Belgian Joris and three Armenians have been condemned to death for complicity in the attempt on the Sultan's life of the 22nd July.

Armed guards and patrols are maintained as looting is feared, H.M.8. Diadem is landing 500 men to-day. The American ship Baltimore is also disembarking a force, and it is reported that German troops are coming from Kiaou-ebau.
A German man-of-war has arrived.

div.head:
ANGLO-GERMAN ENTENTE.
TELEGRAM FROM THE PREMIER.

div.p: Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman has replied to a telegram from the conveners of the meeting of merchants at Berlin for the promotion of an Anglo-German understanding, stating that he entirely reciprocates the desire for the establishment and maintenance of a friendly feeling between the two peoples.

div.head:
SUGAR INDUSTRY OF EGYPT
EFFORT TO REVIVE IT.

div.p: The general meeting of bondholders of the Sorceries has decided to continue to take steps to place the industry in Egypt on a sound footing again, and has requested the defence committee to ask the juge-commis in Cairo to grant sufficient time for the negotiations.

div.p: Competitors in the cap and club prize oom-petitiets are informed that, owing to the greeds having been implayable from rain, the date for the completion of the second rounds has keen prolonged till Wednesday, 2Tth inst. No further extension can be granted, and all matches must be played off by the above-mentioned date.

div.head: THE ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: AS A PUBLIC PARK.
Some divergence of views exists in the Public Works Ministry on the subject of fete in the Esbekieh Gardens. Mr. Perry, in his recently-issued report on these gardens, says:
"It is quite impossible to keep this garden in a proper state unless Government ceases to permit public fetes to be held here.

"I would strongly urge that all fetes be held in the Finance garden at Ghezireh, which does not, like the Esbekieh garden, contain rare botanical specimens, and constitutes the single lung of a large city."

Sir William Garstin comments on these opinions as follows : "I differ from Mr. Perry in one respect. He wishes to keep these gardens closed, and not permit them to be used for fetes, etc. Upon the latter point he maybe right, bat I wish to see these gardens thrown open to the public free of charge, and made into a public park."

div.head: THE NILE SUPPLY.
div.p: As a result of the recent expeditions to the Great lakes it has been discovered that it is upon the level of the Albert lake, that the supply of the Nile depends, and that this sheet of water is the real reservoir, and, to certain extent, the regulator of the Upper Nile. Lake Victoria dischargee a large and varying volume of water into the river channel, below the Ripon Falls, it is true, but, owing to the existence of the chain of swampy lakes —known as Choga—through which it passes for some fifty miles after leaving the upper plateau, the discharge of the river is so regulated, that the volume—due to Lake Viotoria—arriving at Foweira and from there passing on to Lake Albert, is practically constant throughout the year. Any increase below the Murchison Falls is most probably due to rainfall in the catchment area of the lower portion of the Victoria Nile itself, and not to the level of the Victoria Nyanza.

div.head: EGYPT EXPLORATION FUND.
div.p: The Honorary Treasurer of the Egypt Exploration Fund, Mr. H. A. Grueber, has sent the following letter to the "Times":—

"The Egypt Exploration Fund, which was founded in 1883, has every year since that time sent out at least one expedition for arphseo-logical research in Egypt, and has issued to his subscribers an annual memoir giving the results of the work done. During the last two years it sent two such expeditions, under Professor Petrie and M. Naville, whereby the ordinary resources of the fund have been overstrained. In consequence, the committee has resolved that only one expedition can be undertaken in the present season, and circumstances compel that this expedition must be to continue the exploration of the Temple of the XIth Dynasty at Deir el Bahari, which, after two years' work, is left still unfinished. Meanwhile, the agreement with Professor Petrie, which has lasted for nine fruitful years, is suspended by mutual consent; and he is undertaking an independent exploration in the eastern delta of the Nile." After describing the clearing of the Temple of Queen Hathsepshu, at Deir el Bahari by M. Naville, and his discovery with Mr. H.R. Hall, of the British Museum, of the finerary chapel of Mentuhetep III., Mr. Grueber says "During the past two seasons about two-thirds. of the Temple of Mentuhetep have been cleared, but the western end still regains to be excavated. The committee of the fund feel that it is impossible to leave the work in this unfinished state, even for a single winter. They have therefore already sent out Mr. Hall, with other assistants, to continue and (it is hoped) complete operations ; and he will be joined shortly by M. Naville. In view, however, of their depleted finances, they are compelled to make special appeal to their subscribers, and to the general public, in order to enable them to bring to a satisfactory ending an enterprise which has already occupied so-many years, and which has been attended with such valuable results." Contributions may be sent to Mr. Graeber as honorary treasurer.

div.head: REBELLIOUS GREEK PRIESTS
div.p: Some time ago the Holy Synod of Athens, as a disciplinary measure , forbade the Archimandrites of Comis and Monte Santo to celebrate religious services in the Greek church in Venice, whither a new Archimandrite was sent, the two others being ordered to return to Greece. The latter, however, refused to leave the houses they occupy in Venice, which belong to the church. Before leaving Venice, Queen Olga, with her suite, attended service in the Greek church, and while entering the sacred building, her Majesty was addressed by the Archimandrite of Comis, who protested against his punishment. The scene was repeated by the Archimandrite of Monte Santo as the Queen was leaving. Her Majesty was astonished by the audacity of the rebellious prelates, who followed her, continuing their protests. They still flatly refuse to leave Venice.

div.head: THE WILSON NUNGOVICH WEDDING.
div.p: DESCRIPTION OF DRESSES.

The wedding of Miss Nangovich to Captain Wilson, R.A.M.C., which takes place to-day, has attracted general interest, and if the bride's popularity can be ganged by the num her of the presents she has received, Captain Wilson has every cause for congratulation. Miss Nuogovioh's wedding dress is very lovely, and worthy .of the creator, Venture of Milan. It is of fine lace over soft white satin veiled in chiffon. Cat "en Princesse with a moderate train it has the corsage draped with medallions of soft satin outlined with lace, and the same medallions appear in company with bunches of orange blossoms round the hem of the skirt and train. A long spray of orange blossoms is on the bodice, and the tulle veil edged with lace will be kept in place by a small circular diadem of the same flowers.

Miss Marietta Nangovich, who is chief bridesmaid, will look , lovely in her mousse* laine de-soie of palest blush rose, The skirt has three flounces headed with rows of gaugings and over these are flounces of lace embroidered in pale blue. The bodice, is all of lace with bretelles of the pink finished With pearl and diamond ornaments. There is a high corselet of the mousseline da , soie. aufl bands of the same corfine the shorty puffed sleeved. With this is worn a large white Satan iotnre hat draped with white velvet and earing an enormous white ostrich feather. There are two small girl bridesmaids in soft blue Liberty satin frocks veiled in white and with white ribbons in their hair, and the two small pages, one of whom is Master Stephen Nungdvieh, wear white sailor suits with pale blue collars, cuffs and sashes.

Mrs. Nungovioh is wearing a Pa-quin frock of that lovely Sevres blue in Liberty satin. A wide hand of panne the same shade is round the hem of the skirt, and appears on the corsage as rovers. The corsage shows a soft vest of brown satin, which again reveals another vest of chiffon and lovely lace. The hat worn with this is wide spreading, the brim of fine brown suede, the round crown of brown satin. Two gorgeous plumps of Sevres blue fall on one side from a drapery of panne and are kept in place by a huge buckle.
The bride's going-away dress is a plain tailor made of a rough brown check cloth. The hat is a neat small brown felt tamed ap at one side with a quantity of shaded brown roses.

The honeymoon is to be spent at Mena House, but the visit there will be a short one, as the happy pair leave on Boxing Day for Cyprus, where Captain Wilson is at present stationed. Farther details of the wedding and receptionist the 'Savoy Hotel will appear later.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: LAND DEVELOPMENT.
GOVERNMENT RAILWAY CONCESSION AND GUARANTEE.

The first ordinary general meeting of the Corporation of Western Egypt, Limited, was held on the 11th inst., at Cannon Street Hotel, London, E.C., under the presidency of the Hon. Alexander O. Murray, M.P. (chairman of the corporation).
The Secretary (Mr. Alfred W. Deering) read the notice convening the meeting and the report of the auditors.

The Chairman said -.—Gentlemen, it is with great pleasure we meet you to-day in order to submit at the earliest date the position of the corporation, and to ask your adoption of the report and accounts already in your hands, which deal fully with the situation, but concerning which, in the course of my remarks, I propose to offer some explanation. The report and accounts, I presume, you will accept as read. It is my duty in the first instance to remind you that we aid not consider it necessary to issue a prospectus, seeing that the object and scope of our operations were set forth in the concessions from the Egyptian Government, particulars of which were circulated amongst you ; and further, in oar opinion, there was no necessity for such prospectus in view of the fact that, looking to the confidence existing amongst those who launched this enterprise, the capital was at once forthcoming, and, in fact, was very heavily over subscribed. There was accordingly no necessity to make any appeal whatsoever to the public for support. I shall endeavour to show that the continence of the directors, who amongst them hold over 30,000 shares, has been more than justified. I may, however, incidentally mention that it is a matter of gratification to us to have as shareholders influential people, both in this country and in Egypt.

Let me now briefly pass to the consideration of the balance sheet, which, I think, is sufficiently seif explanatory, but concerning which I shall be happy to reply to any questions on the conclusion of my remarks. As regards capital, you will observe that no less than two-thirds of the total capital of the corporation is secured as working capital, in accordance with the arrangement made with the Egyptian Government. You will also observe that, having sufficient capital in hand for present par poses, the final call of 5s per share has been postponed. We have large cash balances, ana so carefully have we invested your funds that the first-claw securities in which they are placed show to-day a greatly enhanced value. With reference to plant, machinery, etc., I should remark that the preliminary pioneering expe ditions therein referred to extended over a senes of many years, and have alone made possible the incorporation of our company. With regard to the item £27,248 5s 11d, included in which is the L.E. 4,000 deposited with the Egyptian Government, we anticipate that a portion of the latter figure will be repayable to us when the account is in due course tendered by the Public Works Department Finally, let me observe while on the subject of accounts that in the first year during which we carried on business we have almost paid our way, being that there is only a debit balance of £1,276 10s 3d standing between us and a diVideud. How, first and foremost among our dividend earning resources stands the land. We are essentially a commercial land company. We have grants of land in Khargeh, Dakhia, Farafra, and Baharia Oases, in Western Egypt. We have grants of land of over 622,000 acres to be taken up pro rata for 30 years over which we have the absolute right of bale. This is one of the most valuable land concessions yet granted by the Egyptian Government, and its careful and economic development should not only provide an outlet for British oapital returning large dividends, but should add a vast revenue producing province to the dominions of the Khedive.

I am happy to state that our relations with the Government are most amicable. Let me impress upon you that we are in no sense a chartered company. The responsibility of policing and public order rests entirely with the Government, with whom we are anxious to work in closest co-operation and to whose opinion we are ready to defer in all administrative matters. We have taken every precaution in oar power to attach to our service officials of the highest calibre, while no less care has been exercised in the Selection of our subordinate officials. Our general manager, Mr. Beckett, came to us bearing most admirable testimonials from influential quarters in India. Mr. Beadnell, who as nine years' representative of the Egyptian Government in the Oases has an unexampled experience of that vast area, has surrendered his position under the Government in order to join our service. He was a member of the Egyptian Survey Department, and is the author of certain official standard publications on Egypt. His geological opinion to the effect that the underground artesian supply in the Oases is practically inexhaustible, and that the output at the surface may be almost indefinitely augmented, together with our own experience during the period under review, shows that Lord Rosebery's saying that "Egypt is the Nile and the Nile is Egypt'' no longer completely holds good, for Mr. Beadneli points oat, with the authority of an expert who has studied local conditions, that "the Oases lands have one great advantage over those of the Nile Valley in that they are not dependent on the time,

volume and duration of the Nile flood." Our several experiments in irrigation have amply demonstrated the fertility of the western country under favorable conditions, and as the report in your hand makes dear, the initial success we have obtained is all' that can be desired. As a consequence we are now receiving numerous applications for land, and as soon as certain formalities are complied with we shall be in a position to proceed with land sales. Meantime we are pushing on survey work in connection with our first application with all possible speed. There is every indica tion that there will be an exceedingly ready sale.

With regard to the value of land, yon will find in Lord Cromer's last report an extract from the report of my colleague Crookshank Pasha relative to the extraordinary value of the Daira Sanieh, which has resulted from his able administration. "Crookshank Pasha," says Lord Cromer, 'writes : "With the conversion of the basin irrigation in Middle Egypt into perennial irrigation, and a constant supply of good water assured by the Assouan dam and Assiout barrage, I am confident that we have not yet reached the highest prices that the land is worth'." And Lord Cromer adds : "This view is shared by many other eminent authorities." The figure for the Nile lands, according to Crookshank Pasha, works out at about £60 per acre. But let us, for the purpose of arriving at some commercial basis for our early land sales in the Oases, assume that £12 10s only per acre will be realised immediately. This calculation would signify no less a sum than £250,000, or the whole of our subscribed capital, from one year's operations. Permit me to remind yon that the Egyptians of all classes have supreme confidence in the commercial value of the land. I may say as one who has had the opportunity, through the kindiy assistance of friends possessing large Egyptian experience, of studying land conditions in Egypt on the spot, that it is very apparent, looking to the marvellous fertility of the soil and to the fact that the Egyptians themselves are continually re investing their profits in it, that the value of land is not a speculative and fluctuating one, but is one which in the future indicates every prospect of showing stable and enhanced prices. Amongst the considerations which weighed with me in accepting the offered position as chairman of this corporation was my profound confidence in the material prosperity and progress of Egypt, and my belief that a land company controlled and managed on sound business lines would be certain to succeed.

The Egyptian is a thrifty and good husbandman, and it will be part of the policy of your directors at a later date to make advances is done by agricultural banks lor the better development of your land in the irrigated districts of your concessions. The company has also in view the taking up and working of land on its own account, and has appointed an agricultural chemist if the highest attainments, who is now engaged in a careful study of local conditions, and in carrying out experiments in the planting of sugar-cane, sisal, ootton and vegetables with complete success. As you know, Lord Cromer speaks in his report of the lack of vegetables in the markets of Cairo, which as you are aware is one of the moat popular of the greatly frequented resorts in the world. We are also giving close attention to the date trade, which has proved so remunerative in Algiers and Tunis, where I understand similar oonditions prevail As regards quality, our land in the Oases is of loamy clay, yielding even in the untutored hands of the local inhabitants rich crops of cereals and knits of many varieties. In regard to labour, I have no fear as to the supply. The surplus population of the Oases, owing to the present lack of adequate employment, trickles to Alexandria, Fort Said, Is-maineh and Cairo. Constant employment should in future retain it at home ; apart from this, there is, however, ample population to draw upon in Egypt proper, parti cularly in the vicinity ol Keneh and Karnao, for whom our railway, when completed, will provide ready transport I may incidentally remind you that the starting point of our line from the State Railway is but a night's journey from Cairo, and that therefore we cannot experience the same difficulties in regard to labour supply as are to be met with at Khartoum, some 1,600 miles from Cairo, and in he Sudan, where the fellaheen are reluctant to emigrate. So cordial are our relations with the Egyptian Government, who, I believe, are fully alive to the earnestness and straightforwardness of our purpose, that there is being prepared at the present time what is practically a free permit to bore wells, though there are, of course, necessary conditions attaching to it Permission has also been granted to us to bore wells for the local inhabitants, and satisfactory terms have already been arranged, which will result in additional revenue to the corporation. I should mention for your information that, for the present, we do not intend to sell any land near actual or possible townships, or in the vicinity of the railway. It may be of interest to those of our shareholders who lean towards antiquarian research to know that signs are not wanting that the present inhabitants are bat a small remnant of a much larger population in ancient times. The Oasis of Khargeh is dotted over with ancient buildings. The ruins of the great temple of Hibis and the remains of many other smaller temples attest the sites of ancient towns under the Egyptian dynasties. Numerous ruined forts and castles of the Roman period bear witness to the size of the garrison and to the importance of the settlements during Imperial times. We have discovered, for example, and opened up a long subterranean watercourse, with vent-holes a intervals. The underground water-channel is doubtless of the same type to be met with in Persia and Balochistan for irrigating purposes. In each the manholes opened up the water
rose too high for the men to continue work with the appliances at their immediate compand.

Respecting subsidiary interests I say very little, as the report deals folly with these subjects. I will only remark that the Dakhia Oasis was known to abound in earthy minerals —phosphates, ochres, etc.; our last year's work shows that the Khargeh Oasis contains important earthy minerals also, chiefly aluminous. In regard to phosphates, Mr. Beadneli, in a report dated October 80th, says: "With regard to the Dakhia deposits, yon will observe from my report that they are practically inexhaustible, and so situated as to be worked with very great facility. ... I have a very high opinion of the Dakhia phosphates ; they are the very best in Egypt, and compare favorably with the best-known foreign deposits." A publication .of the Survey Department,Egyptian Government, on "The Phosphate Deposits of Egypt," says the total area of the phosphate outcrop in Dakhia Oasis is "something like 200 or 250 square kilometres," and further states : "The analyses show that the riohest bands are almost equal to the best Carolina phosphates, and do not compare unfavorably even with the finest Florida deposits." Mr. Bertram Blonnt, F.I.C., the Consulting Chemist to the Crown Agents for the Colonies, to whom we submitted various samples of earthy minerals from the oases, states ' "I have no hesitation in stating that the potential value of these minerals, commercially, is very great." Finally, let me say a word concerning our rail-way.You will doubtless concur with your board that the future of the corporation is mainly wrapped up in the provision of railway facilities between the oases and the Nile. We have, as you are aware, a railway concession for 70 years. We are pushing the line forward with all possible despatch,and are acting under Government supervision, seeing that we are to enjoy a Government guarantee on our capital expenditure. We are constructing the line our-selves, in order that we may save to you the contractors' profits. We have appointed as our supervising engineers the well-known firm of Kincaid, Waller, Manville aud Dawson. Plans of upwards of 30 miles of route have already been approved by the Government, and the permanent way material for that section and the rolling stock for the whole line have already been ordered, and partly shipped. A complete telephone equipment, has also been provided. I must not omit to mention that the survey at the Oasis end of the line is proceeding, aud that the gradients that were at first thought would be somewhat steep will now be considerably lessened. Our general manager, Mr. Beckett, has had as chief engineer of the Bengal-Nagpur Railway, and as its acting general manager, railway experience which will prove of considerable advantage to the corporation in its railway construction. Our railway, when completed, will provide access to markets for agricultural produce ; moreover, it should in view of the great rise in the value of land in the Nile Valley tempt the fellaheen to rent or purchase holdings in the Oases, and thus be instrumental in transforming these once thickly-populated tracts into a busy province again, a province which would participate in the general conditions of prosperity which Anglo-Egyptian beneficent rule has so abundantly brought to Egypt at large. I cannot conclude these remarks without bearing testimony to the unceasing assistance and work which I have received from the officials connected with the company in a consultative capacity and also from the staff both in the London office in Cairo. With these few observations I beg with confidence to submit this report and the accounts for your acceptance and adoption. (Applause).
Mr. C. E. H. Hothouse, M. P., seconded the motion, remarking that he had entire confidence and belief in the undertaking.
The motion was then put and carried unanimously.

Mr. Anderton proposed the re-election of the auditors, Messrs. W. B. Peat and Co., and in doing so stated that the accounts were so clearly set out that there was not the least difficulty in understanding them.
Mr. I. Manville seconded the motion, which was unanimously agreed to.

Mr. Humphrey Ward, in moving a cordial vote of thanks to the chairman and his coleagues, said that as far as his means allowed he had taken a large interest in the oompany. He and his family were the holders of nearly 4,000 shares, and he was sure those present would agree with him that they were all more than satisfied with what had been done. They had been engaged up to the present in more or less pioneer work, but he did not think, that any company of this character had ever at its first meeting been able to give a" more satisfactory account of its operations. ( Hear, hear. ) The accounts were clearly stated ; the working both in England and in this country was carried on in the most businesslike manner; they were on good terms with the Egyptian Government which was, of course, a matter of extreme importance, and they had already ample evi-dence that the goodwill of the large adjoining population of natives was entirely on their side. He wished to express a hope that a year hence, when the shareholders reassembled, the land sales would have yielded satisfactory results, and that, above all, the railway would be, if not in actual working order, at least very nearly so. It was by his railway that Lord Kitchener conquered the Sadan, and it would be by the railway of this company they would conquer the oases. (Applause).
Mr. Anderson seconded the motion, which was unanimously adopted.

The Chairman, on behalf of his colleagues and himself, thanked the shareholders for their very kind Words of encouragement to the board, and assured them that no efforts would be spared on their side to promote and advance the interests of the shareholders to the best of their ability. (Applause).
The proceedings then terminated.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUE!
Le Caire, 18 décembre
A Londres, le Consolidé a baissé hier de 3/8 de livre, après avoir, il est vrai, haussé de 3/4 samedi dernier. Les valeurs égyptiennes sont encore testées in variées.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier a regagné 2 francs à 772. Les Sucreries d'Egypte ont encore perdu 1 franc à 21.
Ici, le marché n'est pas très animé. On fait fort peu d'affaires en National Bank et en Agricole, qui cotent respectivement 25 5/32 et 9 1/8 acheteur. Le Crédit Foncier est stationnaire à 777.
L'action Enterprise and Development avance à 12 1/2 ; la part de fondateur est demandée en clôture à 9 1/8.
Les improprement Corporation sont termes à 4 1/8. Les Agricoles du Nil s'inscrivent à 285. Les actions Ciments rsstent à 75 ; les dividendes reculent à 33.
Les Dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie sont malmenés depuis quelques jours. Ils baissent aujourd'hui à 298.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Baehler sont en bonne demande et avancent à 3 1/8. Lee Nungovioh sont offerts à 10 19/32.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Estâtes don-nent, comme ton jours, lieu à de nombreuses transactions; ils clôturent! f 1/2 vendeurs. Les Sait and Soda baissent à 19/6.
Les Oasis sont offerte an dessous du pair. Par contre, les Investiront Abdy sont recherchés à 1 1/16.
On transmet d'Athènes quelques détails intéressants concernant la transformation imminente de la Banque d'Orîent

Cette institution avait été fondée, an communément de l'année courante, par la Banque Nationale de Grèce et la National bank fur Deutschland de Berlin, avec siège central à Athènes, et des agences à Constantinople, Smyrne, Salonique, Alexandrie et Hambourg.

Or, des dissentiments s'étant produits par suite du désir de la National bank de s'immiscer dans les détails de l'administration et du personnel, une solation à l'amiable vient d'inter-veair entra Les parties. La Banque d'Orient conserve pour elle les établissements d'Athènes, Srayrne, Salonique, Alexandrie, ainsi que celui qui est à la veille de s'ouvrir au Caire. Elle cède, par courte, à la Natioualbank für Deuts-eklknd les agences de Constantinople et de Hambourg, sur la base de leur valeur au 81 déoembie courant.
La Nationalbank se propose d'inoorporer ces deax agences dans une nouvelle Banque, à créer par un groupe allemand, qui tara pour rayon d'action tonte la Méditerranée.
L'assembla. générale des actionnaires de l'Egyptian Enterprise and Development Company est convoquée pour le samedi 20 Janvier 1906, à 4 h. p m., an siège social an Caire.
Ordre du jour : 1. Rapport du Conseil d'ad-mibistration: sur l'exercice écoulé ;2. Approbation du bilan au 31 Décembre 1905 ; 3. Fixation du dividende ; 4. Nomination d'an commissaire.

La New Egyptian Co. informe ses apticppqi-res qa'ils peuvent toucher le premier dividende, soit 2 sh. 6d, par action, sur la presentation, du coupon No. 1, an siège social à Londres ou bien an bureau delà Société An Caire.
Les cours do coton sont eu baisse en Amérique. Le "spot" a perdu 5 points ; le Janvier et le Mai ont fléchi de 17 pointe.
Le marché de Liverpool est également pins faible.
Les arrivages sont toujours restreints : 44 000 balles contre 55.000.
Ici le Mars a ouvert, ce matin, a 15 27/32 vendeurs, pour clôturer a 16.
Suivant un télégramme que nous recevons de Liverpool, on pronostique que la récolte aux États-Unis ne dépassera pas 9,350,000 balles.

MM. H. de Vries et Boutigny, agente de change, se chargent de réexécution de tous ordres de Bourse (vachers et marchandises) sur les marchés de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, Anvers, Liverpool et New-York. La Circulaire quotidienne de la maison est envoyée sur demande.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: COUR D'APPEL MIXTE.
Barthélémy Carbonel contre Ernest Mebcinier et Léon Stienon

M. Carbonel, ayant servi d'intermédiaire entre Me Meroinier et le Sr. Goneim an sujet d'on procès qne celui-ci avait intenté à Haridi en revendication d'une propriété deoentfeddans, prétend qu'aux termes d'an accord avec Me Meroinier il devait toucher la moitié dos honoraires promis, an oas où son olient aurait gain de cause. Le Sr. Goneim gagna effectivement son procès, et récompensa royalement son avocat, mais oelni-oi se défendit d'avoir rien à partager aveo Carbonel
De là le procès actuel Le tribunal de première instance a donné raison à Me Meroinier, mais Carbonel a fait appel de ce premier jugement.
La Cour vient de se ranger a la décision des premiers juges et de condamner l'appelant aux dépens.
Voici les principaux motifs invoqués dans l'arrêt :

L'appelant ne fournit pas aux débats la preuve du prétendu dol qui l'aurait empêché de se procurer une oontre-lettre, et auoun des faits par lai articulés dans son exploit da 18 novembre 1905 ne tendent à le démontrer. L'assertion d'après laquelle les mots "que M. Stienon a payé avant ces présentes, eto." auraient été frauduleusement mis par l'offioier publio quiareça l'acte da 31 mai 1899 à l'insu de l'appelant est manifestement invraisemblable. En tous cas, la preuve d'un fait de cette nature infirmant la sincérité de l'officier publié et impliquant sa participation au dol doit être îourni non par une simple enquête mais à la suite et sous la garantie de l'insoription en faux.

Qaant à la nullité tirée de l'art. 324 du Code Civil, il est acquis aux débats qu'au moment où intervenait l'aote précité da 31 mai, le procès entre Goneim et Haridi était complètement terminé au profit du premier. 11 ne s'agissait dono point d'une vente portantsnr droits litigieux mais simplement de la rémunération par un olient reconnaissant de services prêtés aveo le plus grand succès par son avocat
De plus Carbonel n'apparaissant à l'aote que comme prête-nom, on ne saurait prononcer la nullité en l'absence da véritable intéressé ou de ses héritiers.

Il est vrai que la dite nullité pourrait aux termes de l'art 324 être prononcée d'office, mais cela ne veut pas dire qu'elle doive être prononcée en dehors de la partie intéressée et même incidemment.

div.head: TRIBUNAL MIXTE DU CAIRE
div.p: Une Affaire de Préemption

Le Tribunal mixte de Ire instance du Caire (2me Chambre civile) a rendu hier son jugement dans une intéressante affaire de préemption. Cette affaire a été plaidée la semaine dernière. Voici les faits de la oause, tels d'ailleurs que nous les avons déjà exposés :

La Delta fait observer que son acte d'achat à elle est transcrit, tandis que celai de son adversaire ne l'est pas. Mais cette dernière fait remarquer que la priorité de son acquisition est incontestable, de l'aveu même de la Delta Land, et par le fait qne dans l'acte de vente de œlle-oi, elle, Mounira Hanem est indiquée oomme propriétaire limitrophe. Elle ajoute que la transcription ne saurait avoir auonn effet quant à l'existence du droit de préemption, création du droit musulman et basée uniquement sur la priorité de l'acquisition, ce qui est une simple question de fait.
La Delta Land a répondu en soutenant qne la transcription était indispensable pour l'exercice da droit de préemption.
Tel est le problème qu'a en à résoudre le Tribunal. Le gros lot dans cette affaire s'élevait à la modeste somme d'une vingtaine de mille livres.

Dans son jugetaeüt rendu hier, la 2me Chambra civile a déclaré erronée la thèse de la Société en établissant qu'il s'agit en l'espèce "de statuer sur les rapports entre deux voisins sur la question de savoir lequel des deux par préférence à l'antre est justifié dans son droit de préempter. Voici au surplus le dispositif du jugement :

"Statuant contradictoirement, rejette la prescription de la Delta Land and Inversement Company, Limited comme non justifiée et faisant droit sur la préemption de la Dame Mounira et Kairy bey la déclare bien fondée, dit par exception que moyennant paiement de la somme de LE. 11.801 et des irais et loyaux coûts qm setont justifiée la Delta Land and Investmeot Company, Limited en la personne de son directeur M. A. Adams, sera tenue de remettre la parcelle préemptée sous peine des oonaéqaenoes légales ; condamne la Delta Land and Investment Company, Limiter aux frais, y comprit tes honoraires de la défense taxés à P. T. 400.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: {Communication Officielle}
La Dé'égation Municipale s'est réunie le 19 Décembre 1905, à 4 h. p.m. sous la présidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli.
Présents: MM. E. Benaobi, P. Fenderl, Mansoar Bey Yaussef, E Stross, Soliman Bey Abani, Dr. G. Valensin, G. Zervodaohi, membres, W. P. Chataway, administrateur, I. Sedky Bey, secrétaire.

Sur rapport des Services, la Délégation adjuge à M. Autofage,auxprix de sou offre du 12 Déc. 1905, la fourniture d'articles divers, nécessaires au fonctionnement des rouleaox compresseurs, pendant l'année 1906.

Une question relative à la fourniture de pierres par l'entreprise Almag:à ( pour la confection de la route corniche, sera soumise à la prochaine séance de la Commission Mnnioipale, l'administrateur étant chargé, en attendant, d'en régler les détails.

La Délégation s'occupe de la question du transfert des éohèohes du Gabbari et de celles de Toubguieh et, après un échange d'idées, prie l'administratenr de s'entendre aveo le Gouvernement pour oe transfert.

Se rangeant à la manière de voir du Ministère, la Délégation décide d'apporter à l'arrêté sur la malléinisation obligatoire des solipèdes, les modifications suggérées par le Gouvernement, sauf pour la question de l'indemuité à allouer, qui reste fixée à un maximum de L E. 20.

Communication est donnée d'ane lettre da 12 Décembre 1905, do Ministère de l'Intérieur, informant que le Ministère des Finances n'a pas d'objection à accéder à la demande de la Municipalité, tendant à ne pas consentir de vente de terrains de l'Etat, à Ghebel Guillé, sans l'en prévenir, et ce, pour le cas où la Municipalité aurait l'intention d'y établir le destructeur d'immondices.
La Délégation prend note d'une lettre de M. Zouro portant diverses interpellations qu'il fera à la Commission Mnnioipale.—L'Administrateur donne, à ce sujet, les explications voulues.
Aucune offre n'ayant été présentée pour la fourniture de caissons de vidanges, la Délégation charge le Service Technique de lui présenter un rapport pour fonctionnement de ce servioe en régie.

Communication est donnée d'une lettre de S.E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur, d'après laquelle il serait d'avis de remettre jusqu'à la promulgation du réglement général, qn'il est en train d'élaborer sur la navigation, le projet de la Municipalité, relatif an canal Mahmondieh.

La Délégation fait observer qu'il ne pourra y avoir de contradiction entre la réglementation de l'Etat et celle de la Municipalité, la première conoernant la navigation, et la seconde l'acoostage et l'occupation des berges.

En réponse à une demande de la Municipalité, l'Administration des chemins de ter de l'Etat informe que les offres pour l'élargissement du pont-route du Gabbary, ont été demandées pour le 25 Décembre 1905.
La Dé'égation approuve le projet élaboré avec l'Etat pour l'aménagement d'nne place de 2000 m c. an dessus de l'hypogée de Ras-el -Tin.

Elle décide, sur la demande de l'Administration des Douanes, de prolonger de quelques mètres, le dallage de la rue du Pétrolenm Stores et décide de confier ce travail à l'entrepreneur des premiers travaux, au prix proportionnel de son forfait.
Sur devis des Services, la Dé'égation dé-oide de mettre en adjudication les travaux de dallave de la rue Ramsès III.

La Délégation proposera à la Commission, outre la dépense de L.E. 212, votée à la dernière séance pour l'installation d'une canalisation destinée à l'arrosage du terre-plein, situé autour da la Colonne Pompée, une nouvelle dépeuse de LE. 206 pour la transformation en jardins de oe terre plein.

Eu outre, et sauf avis du Comité des plantations, elle proposera à la Commission une demande de M. Monfront, tendant i l'ouverture d'un crédit de L E. fi 00 pour commencer certains travaux de jardinage, au jardin Nouzba, afin de permettre d'y fairs les plantations et transplantations en temps opportun.
La Délégation arrête l'ordre du jour de la prochaine séance de la Délégation.

div.head: THEATRE ALHAMBRA
div.p: Le mauvais temps avait empêohé beaucoup de monde d'aller aa théâtre hier soir ; mais le petit nombre de personnes qui assistaient à la représentation de "Mademoisslle Ni touche", n'out pas regretté leur soirée.
Mlle Lambertini a été exquise en Mademoiselle Ni touche, ainsi d'aiîleurs que M. Simon en Célestin et M. Coutelier en Fernand. M. Ballin a soulevé une tempête de gaieté dans son rôle de Loriot.
Ce soir, on donne "La Poupée", opéra-comique de Maurice Ordonnean, musique d'Audran. Mlle Lambertiôi jouera le rô'e d'Aléeia.
