div.head: OUR PARIS LETTER.
div.p: Paris, December 13

Paris is at present enjoying a spell of first-rate weather. The temperature is low in comparison with the abnormally warm weather of last week, when a butterfly, which must have lost its way, was seen fluttering round the Madeleine, but the bright sunshine which prevailed during the greater part of yesterday and to-day was a welcome compensation, on Sunday we had a lovely full moon, and, unlike Londoners, Parisians were able to see it. We have had no fog at all for some weeks, and in the early morning and late at night real winter conditions prevail; hard frost and clear, bright air. Let ns hope that this sort of thing will continue until after the New Year, for if it does not, the shopkeepers will lose a lot of money. People here begin making their Christmas and New Year purchases immediately after December sets in, and if we are not blessed with a fair amount of good weather during the last month of the year, there is much less done in the way of shopping than would otherwise be the case.

As usual, a good many people are preparirg to spend the end of the year where the son shine?, and departures for the Riviera are becoming every day more numerous. While, of course, to those of a domestic turn of mil d there is nothing like a Christmas among the old folks and one's own family, it seems to me that when one has really enjoyed the delights of a winter in the South of France, when one has left London enveloped in fog and smoke and cold and in less than twenty-four hours has woke up in a Valmy atmosphere, a blue sky above, sunshine streaming through the carriage windows, and the azure Mediter ranean at one's feet, it is difficult to forget the sensation, and not easy to get over the longing to enjoy it all over again. It does not much matter at what part of the coast you decide to bask in the sunshine, you will find the sons of Britain comfortably installed at all the best stopping places, from Hyeres to Mentone.

The political situation is by no means dear. Speech is added to speech across the Rhine, and the effect of so much oratory is to increase the apprehensions of those who believe that there is some ulterior motives in all these appeals to the Chauvinism of the Reichstag. If ary confirmation were needed of the pessimistic view, it is to be found in the comments of the German Press, which become increasingly provocative. Amongst serious-minded persons the gloomiest opinions prevail as to the tendencies of the hour. It is believed that no stone will be left unturned to embarrass England and France at Algeciras, even to the point, if need be, of organising a native "coup" in Morocco during the time the Conference sits. Nor are the veiled threats of Germany lost upon the most pacific of public writers. France, also, is keeping its sword sharpened and its powder dry. Since the "fronsse" every eff rt has been made to bring the defence forces of the Eastern frontier into a state of the utmost preparation. Before the end of the year is out the last (cartridge will have been delivered and the last button adjusted on the military gaiter.

That strange and cynical deity, which is Chance, has played directly into the hands of a watchful enemy. The election in England will be succeeded by the elections in France. Whilst Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman and his colleagues are probably as Francophil as their predecessors,observers are not slow to note that they are more Teutophil at the same t me. Those who foresee the possibility of a conflict are not assured by the thought that a Liberal Government will be in office in England, whose pacific sentiments, excellent as they may be, are apt to be expressed in lowered credits for the Navy. Meanwhile, the German shipyards are chock-a-block with new work. Nor is it possible to deny the blackness of the French internal situation. The Rouvier Ministry, under an appearance of solidarity, is trembling to its fall. The great season for homogeneity the separation of Church and State—has departed with the passage of the hill through the two Chambers. When, on previous occasions, the Socialists threatened to desert, M. Rouvier had merely to murmur "Separation Bill" to bring them to an obedient state of mind. But to use an Americanism, the Extreme left "has no further use for" M. Rouvier.

The question of the successor of M. Loubet is beginning to occupy everyone in Paris to the exclusion of all other subjects. There is no doubt that many quiet citizens would he glad if the President would consent to serve for another term, but this M. Loubet has declined to do, and the uncertainty as to the future has caused a curious agitation The Socialists and some others dread the election

of M. Doumer, the returned proconsul, and in the hope of seeing him beaten, they have started a theory that the President of the Republic ought to be elected by open vote, and not by the ballot. But whether M. Doumer will gain by the ballot or not, there is no doubt that the voting for the Presidency has always been, and was meant to be, secret. It is true that the Constitutional Law of 187 5 is not clear, for the paragraph referring to the President says, "The President of the Re-public shall be elected by a majority of voters in the National Assembly." But in the commentary of M. Pierre, it is stated that the President is to be elected in the manner and according to the roles appointed for the emotion of the Bureaux of the Chamber of Deputies, and this election has always been by ballot. Moreover, during the Second Republic, in 1852, it was laid down that the vote was to be secret, so that it is evident that vote by ballot has always been regarded as a necessity in a Presidential election. If the Socialist proposal were ratified by Parliament, it would be nothing less than a revolution, and it is difficult to see what would be the advantage of such a reversal of all precedent, more especially as it is, to say the least of it, doubtful whether M. Doumer's chances would be in the slightest degree injured by recourse to an open vote.

With regard to this years's automobile show, which was opened on Friday by President Lou bet, accompanied by more than half-a-dozen members of the Cabinet, experts tell us that there is no striking novelty, but that the general standard of efficiency and excellence is considerably higher than twelve months ago. Cars are gradually falling into line with modern civilised requirements. They do not smell To badly as they did at t he beginning, they are less noisy, and it is now possible to take a trip in them without being obliged to strap yourself to the seat. They also coat less money,and that is perhaps where there was the greatest room for modification. At one time it was no use looking for a decent car without a thousand-pound note to spend. To-day enthusiasts are speaking of the poor man's car, which shall be sold for a hundred pounds. The wonderful progress made by Franoe in the motor-car industry is illustrated by the following figures :— In 1898, the first year of the annual exhibition, the number of visitors to the show was 82,000, in 1904 the attendances had risen to 360,000. and this year it is expected that before the Salon Automobile closes its doors on Christmas Eve, it will have been visited by at least 500,000 people. In 1903 France exported motor-cars to the value of £2,033,080; in 1904 the exports had attained to £2,852,080;; and the figures for the first ten months of this year are £3,848,888.

The amber roof of the Grand Palais in the Champs Elysees shines like a beacon for miles. The exhibition is a wonderful demonstration of art and industry. It is certainly the most handsome Salon that has ever been. Each exhibitor has his own electric installation, often of a very elaborate kind, in addition to the great Sun and attendant stars that shine down upon him from the roof. One manufacturer has spent the bagatelle of £1,400 upon his iHuminatiocs. The Salon d'Automobile has become one of the great social fetes of Paris. It is as important as the official picture exhibition in the spring, as the horse show which succeeds it, or the Grand Prix. Women order their frocks for the motor exhibition, just as they do for those other great events. The "Anto" rope keeps the Rae de la Paix as busy as if it were making for the Grande Semaine. The Avenne Nicholas, which stretch* es before the doors of the Grand Palais, is filled the day through with the sights and sounds of automobile life. There is the loud trump of horns, the throbbing of a thousand engines, and the "va et vient" incidental to a flying column of horseless carriages.

The Freuoh Maritime League has taken the lead in commemorating the centenary of the launching of the first steamboat by Fulton in 1807. While, however, according to America the honors in the matter of navigation, France claims to have been the first nation to adopt steamships in the merchant service, and Paris proposes to honor both these events by an international exhibition to he held in the city in 1907. A monument is to he erected to Fulton and another to Jonflroy d'Abbaue, who, according to French claims, first applied steam to naval service.

It is a long time since the sale of any one single collection of paintings, sculpture, porce lain, and general art objects has produced results anything approaching those yielded by the Cronier collection this week. It may be doubted, indeed if they have been equalled anywhere within the past two years. After the paintings the keenest competition seems to have been for the antique furniture with Beauvais and Anbusson upholsterings, and for the Beauvais, Aubusson, and Gobelins tapestries. Altogether the sale has yielded
£208,000. Its highest figure given for a piece of Beauvais tapestry was £12,000 for Bouche's 'Sisters of Psyche." The top figure in Gobelins was £8,000 for a "History of Don Qaixote."

Motor cabs are forging steadily ahead in Paris. A good many are already on the streets, and within two or three weeks they will be followed by 250 more. Like the horsed vehicles hey will be fitted with taximeters, on a scale which may not be without its interest for British proprietors and drivers. The tariff is as follows : Sevenpence-halfpenny for the first 930 yards, and one penny for each 809 yards afterwards, which brings the rate, roughly, to about tenpence halfpenny per mile.

A strange case of violation of old tombs has recently taken place in Paris, not in an open cemetery, but within the precincts of Mont Valerien, perhaps the most powerful of the doomed forts girdling the city. The tomb is that of the Duo de Fleury, who was buried in the fortress in 1815. A committee periodically examines this and a few other tombs in the enceinte, and at their last inspection found that the Duke's tomb had been broken into, a lead coffin forced, and various objects of value inside abstracted. Careful inquiry led to the arrest of a sapper of the garrison, whose term of service would have expired next September. On interrogation he admitted that two ex-soldiers of the garrison, now discharged, had plotted the robbery, and that he had abetted them. He has not divulged the names of his accomplices.

Paris has just been celebrating the centenary of Robert Houdin, the father of modern magic, who was horn, the son of a watchmaker, at Blois in 1805. All the conjurors of modern times acknowledge their indebtedness to Hon-din, who, while working in his father's shop, determined to become a professor of magic, and began to construct those ingenious mechanical tricks by which he later on astonished the world. Before his time conjurors always appeared in the fantastic costume of a "wizard," with a pointed cap and a flowing robe, and their mechanical devices were limited to the box with a double bottom. But on July 3rd, 1845, Robert Houdin appeared in evening dress at the Palais Royal, and performed a number of absolutely new tricks, all of which were mechanical and extremely ingenious. Within a week he was famous, and for seven years he travelled all over Europe, and even in North Africa, his most remarkable achievements being bis performance before the Pope and his defeat of the Arab sorcerers. Houdin was a handsome, distinguished, and witty man, and the comments with which he accompanied his tricks, now familiarly known as "patter," added greatly to his success. In the franco-Prussian war he had the misfortune to lose his second son, a young officer of promise, and in 1872, he died, having elevated conjuring from an object of derision to a source of wonder and astonishment.

div.head: AGRA BEADS.
div.p: One of the curious historical phenomena in relation to ancient industries is the existence of these beautiful curiosities, which have been dug up in West Africa, and which would seem to be of ancient Phoenician manufacture. These beads are made of solid enamel of the purest kind. They form the most prized earthly possession of the old native families of the Gold Coast, who cannot be induced to part with them. Those that are met with elsewhere may he generally pronounced to he imitations. So much prized are the real beads that it is difficult to get the possessors even to show them ; only the direst want will make them yield possession. The fact that these heads are fonnd buried in the earth in ancient villages gives colour to the idea that they were used as a barter in dealings by the ancient Phoenician traders, who exchanged their wares fo- the gold which was undoubtedly worked in this part of Africa at a very early date. The reason for this early working of these particular deposits is that the gold is universally disseminated over the whole country, and panning, the most ancient form of mining, can be adopted at any river or at any of the large alluvial deposits in West Africa. It would be very interesting to know whether in the workings of the Egyptian and Sudan mines, now so actively taking place, any traces of similar enamels have been found. No doubt the form and the substance more or less of this merchandise or medium of exchange differed considerably according to the tastes of the various communities. But any trace of such heads, made of the solid enamel of any shape or colour, would be an interesting discovery.

In order that excavators may recognise these beads we would say that they are generally extraordinarily light in weight, although solid enamel. The imitations are always heavier than the enguine beads.

div.head: P. & O. STEAM NAVIGATION CO.
div.p: The annual meeting of this company was he'd last week at their offices in Leadenhall-street. Sir Thos. Sutherland presided and moved the adoption of the report, which proposed a return for the year equal to nine per cent, on the paid-up capital of £2,320.000. He thought the meeting would be satisfied with it. They paid the usual dividend and bonus to which the shareholders had been accustomed for some years on the moderate capital of the company. Their total sinking fund for the year was £536,000 ; this was the very backbone of their business; it was the means by which they had continued the improvement and expansion of their fleet. Their total revenue was upwards of three millions sterling. Perhaps the most interesting item was that of passage money £981.695, an increase over the previous year of £26,000; this increase followed upon a similar increase in the previous year, and it showed that the general tendency of trade was towards improvement. In the case of the Australian colonies the advance was far less than had been expected. They had hoped with the return of better times to find a larger increment in their passenger business; but all their advices tended to show that whatever increase they obtained in the past year was merely to he considered as an angary of better things in the immediate future. As to the passenger fares, he found that on their line to Bombay, which was their most expensive line, the return obtained by the company was at the rate of 1 1/4d. per mile; on their China line to Japan and Australia the figures amounted to within a fraction of 1d. per mile ; whereas on the Calcutta line, which was no longer a main line, and which employed fewer vessels, the actual return was considerably below 1d. per mile. In goods freights there was a decrease of £37,230. While their basic ess with Australia was a matter of considerable disappointment, they had had a most excellent trade in connection with China and Japan; but he was not sanguine as to shipping prospects for next year. From the 1st of January next the Suez Canal Company had reduced their imposts to an extent that wonld save the company in twelve months £30,000 or upwards. He gave an account of the progress of the oompany daring the 25 years he had been chairman, stating that while they got less for mails and did much more work for it, passenger fares had been rednoed 30 per cent; their oarryirg tonnage had been increased 250,000 tons in capacity, they had paid £5,000.000 in dividends, and had laid aside out of earnings no less than nine millions sterling. — The report was adopted without discussion.

div.head: DOMESTIC HARMONY
div.p: When husband and wife disagree, as a rule, neither is to blame. Perhaps the husband, overworked at business, is depressed, nervous and irritable; the wife, on her side, excitable and bodily weak. This weakness proceeds either from a disordered digestion or a general state of low health resulting from the numerous ailments of the weaker sex.

Dr. Williams' Pink Pills restore harmony in the house, for they give tone to the overwrought nerves, impart an appetite and power to digest food, and enrich and purify the blood, while in women they give regular health and the strength that is necessary for everyday worries in the home. My appetite left me, and even the lightest food would lie heavy on my chest, until life seemed a perfect misery. A doctor stated I was suffering from gastric catarrh, and about this time my nervons system was so run down that my sight was affected.
"Nothing seemed to remove the feeling of depression and weakness that had come over me. So I grew weaker and more nervous ; I was really terrified at the thought of being left alone.

"One day. however, my husband bought me a box of Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People. I began to feel better after the first few pills and you can imagine my husband's joy. With one box my appetite improved greatly and the pains in the head vanished. After three boxes of the pills I felt as well and as strong as ever I did in my life. It is wonderful to think that Dr. Williams' Pink Pills effected what no other medicine could do."

Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
